description: Coined by Alfred Nobel in 1867. Ultimately from Ancient Greek δύναμις (dúnamis, “power”)  +‎ -ite, most likely under the influence of dynamo or dynamic.

entries.meaning: A class of explosives made from nitroglycerine in an absorbent medium such as kieselguhr, used in mining and blasting.
(figuratively, slang, uncountable) Anything exceptionally dangerous, exciting or wonderful.
examples: That girl was dynamite. Dark hair with killer blue eyes, bronze skin, and an exquisite full-figured body.
He warned us: "That issue about what's been happening at that factory, is political dynamite. Keep the lid on it."

entries.meaning: (slang) A strong drug, in particular heroin, cocaine or potent marijuana.

verbs.description: dynamite (third-person singular simple present dynamites, present participle dynamiting, simple past and past participle dynamited)

entries.meaning: To blow up with dynamite or other high explosive.

examples: Even the successful battle in the last century to overturn the court’s infamous Plessy vs. Ferguson “separate but equal” doctrine wasn’t a frontal assault that dynamited precedent.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of brakes) To apply maximum pressure to very quickly.
(intransitive, of brakes) To lock up from being invoked too suddenly.
